Description: Copper-alloy arrow-head; leaf-shaped with tang (now broken). A shallow central rib is barely visible beneath corrosion on both sides. Edges are rounded near the tip. Corroded.
Curator's comments: This oblanceolate tanged arrow-head belongs to an Egyptian form not found in Greece, or the Middle East, but has been found in Israel. See BM EA 1885,1101.94 also from Naukratis and parralels from Tell Dafan BM EA 1887,0101.1439 and compare with similar BM GR 1935,0823.114, 1887,0101.1440. Similar arrowheads found at Ashkelon in 7th century BC contexts (Aja 2011, 536, nos 78-82) and this type is replaced with the introduction of Scythian types during Persian rule in the 6th century BC (ibid. 513). It is likely an early form that was abandoned early in Naukratis' history. Aja, A. J. 2011, 'Metal weapons and tools', in L. E. Stager, D. M. Master and J. D. Schloen, Ashkelon 3: the 7th century BC, Indiana, 503-45.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (SB.05) (Phase 2)
